Before attempting to take this apart I would have tried to do some electrolytic de-rusting. I would have left it soak for a day or two in the electrolysis tank. That would have taken care of most of the rust and might have helped with dislodging the seized bolts. Then, when attempting to remove the seized bolts, I would have tried a blowtorch on them first instead of going directly for the brute force method.

If you want to remove zinc plating from store bought bolts/nuts you can buy cheap toilet bowl cleaner (anything that removes rust as well as stains...CLR, cheap store brand, etc). Let your parts soak in the concentrate for a few hours. It'll work faster if you put it in the sun, or somewhere warm. Parts will rust quickly, so either oil them or paint them.

That welder sounds a little too cold, you should be getting a nice frying bacon sound if you're using straight hard-wire mild steel filler. If your machine can muster it, try around 18.5v and 235 wirespeed (Should be in inches per minute, sometimes just listed as a value of 1-10 for example, conversion should be in your machine manual or setting page inside the wire compartment), for your settings and play around with them there, it looks and sounds off. If you can use a 220/250V circuit for your welder, I would recommend even 20.5v and 288 wirespeed on the settings.
